Laboratory of Alternative Energy Conversion Systems Department of Mechanical Engineering School of Engineering University of Thessaly Pedion Areos 38834 Greece Graphical abstract Lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries are considered as promising candidates for future energy storage systems due to their super-high theoretical energy densities. However, the poor cyclic stability and low efficiency still hinder their commercialization, which is mainly attributed to the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) processes. In the present work, we fabricated a three-dimensional (3D) air cathode composed of CoNiO2 nanoneedles decorated N-doped porous carbon nanonet (CoNiO2/SCC-N), using silkworm cocoons as the raw materials and following the carbonization-hydrothermal route. The as fabricated batteries, with CoNiO2/SCC-N air cathode, are exhibited a very good discharge capacity of 1654 mAh g−1 cathode at a current density of 0.05 mA cm-2, presenting a stability of over 147 cycles. The observed electrochemical performance is attributed to the synergistic effect of the enhanced ORR/OER activity after the introduction of CoNiO2 and the efficient mass transport characteristics of SCC-N. Keywords Li-O2 battery CoNiO2 Free-standing cathodes Electrocatalytic ORR/OER activity 1 Introduction Rechargeable non-aqueous Li-O2 batteries have attracted worldwide attention due to their super-high theoretical energy density (11,400 Wh kg−1) [1–3]. However, numerous challenges have to be overcome before their commercialization, such as large discharge/charge overpotential, low practical energy density, poor cycle stability, and parasitic side reaction, which are related to the performance of the cathode [3,4]. Similar to proton exchange membrane fuel cells [5,6], the reaction occurred at the cathode of Li-O2 batteries is a complex electrochemical process, taking place in the three-phase “solid-liquid-gaseous” interface [7]. During the discharging process, insoluble discharge products (Li2O2) gradually accumulated on the surface or within the pores of the cathode, which can block the transport channels of O2 and electrolyte and isolate oxygen from the catalysts, causing discharge termination. On the contrary, sufficient decomposition of Li2O2 during charging is a necessary condition for maintaining battery cycle. Based on previous literature reports, design and construction of cathodes with proper porous structure, efficient oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and efficient oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalytic activity, is the key to achieve highly performing Li-O2 batteries. Up to now, various kinds of catalysts have been employed to enhance the performance of Li-O2 batteries, including noble metals, doped carbon materials, transition metal oxides and so on. The noble metals (e.g. Pt, Pd, Au, Ir, etc.) are considered as the most effective ORR/OER electrocatalysts [8–10]. Nevertheless, rarity and high cost restrict their scale applications. Doped carbon materials have been widely used in Li-O2 batteries, due to their low cost and high conductivity [11,12]. Although the N-doped carbon exhibited better ORR activity than commercial XC-72, the charge potential is still higher than 4 V, which may lead to the decomposition of the electrolyte [13]. Transition metal oxides usually exhibit satisfactory OER activity for Li-O2 battery, but their performance depends on improving the electrical conductivity, dispersion and exposing more active sites. Gong et al. [14] synthesized NiCo2O4/N-rGO catalyst for Li-O2 batteries and reported that NiCo2O4 nanoparticles ensured a great catalytic activity for OER and protected rGO from corrosion. Song et al. [15] synthetized a hybrid of mesoporous CoO functionalized on the rGO for the catalyst of Li-O2 batteries. The charge overpotential of CoO/rGO was significantly reduced compared with that of CoO and rGO, attributed to the synergistic effect between the high OER catalytic activity of CoO and the high conductivity of rGO. As previously stated, the performance of Li-O2 batteries also depends strongly on the pore structure of the cathode. The traditional electrode preparation technology, spraying the slurry containing catalyst, conductive additive and binder on the collector, usually faces problems; the active sites of catalyst are covered up and at a high potential the binder may be decomposed. In addition, the pore size distribution, of electrodes prepared by this method, is mostly concentrated in the microporous range, resulting in the ease cathode passivation by Li2O2. Furthermore, the preparation process is time-consuming and laborious. The in situ growth of catalysts on three-dimensional (3D) supports (Ni foam, carbon paper and others) for the preparation of 3D free standing cathodes is found to be an effective strategy to eliminate the negative influences of the traditional preparation technology [16–18]. The specific capacity and cyclic performance reported in the literature are usually based on the mass of the catalyst; the specific capacity can be as high as 10,000 mA h g−1 (the mass of the catalyst is usually 0.3–1 mg cm-2). However, in practice, the mass specific energy density of the Li-O2 battery is calculated by the total weight of the cathode, including the catalyst support (although Ni foam and carbon paper don’t possess catalytic activity). Therefore, the actual capacities are only 1/10 or even 1/20 times of the results reported in the literatures, calculating based on the whole cathode. For improving the actual energy density of Li-O2 batteries it is necessary to develop 3D free-standing supports with superior catalytic activity. In a previous work, we have successfully prepared 3D free-standing N-doped carbon network derived from silkworm cocoon (SCC-N) by employing a simple method [12]. The specific capacity reached up to 1200 mA g−1 cathode at a current density of 0.02 mA cm-2. The macroporous structure of the carbon nanonet facilitated the transport of oxygen and electrolyte. Additionally, N elements derived from the protein in silkworm cocoon were doped into the carbon structure after high temperature calcination, which confirm the good catalytic performance of SCC-N. This method provides a feasible way to prepare 3D free-standing supports with superior catalytic activity for Li-O2 batteries. Unfortunately, due to the poor OER catalytic activity of N-doped carbon, the cycle stability and the rate performance were not satisfactory. CoNiO2, an interesting half-metallic material with excellent electrical conductivity [19], has been reported as a potential candidate electrode material for lithium ion batteries [20,21], sodium ion batteries [22,23] and supercapacitors [24–26]. In addition, CoNiO2 has been explored as a highly active catalyst in ethanol electro-oxidation reaction in alkaline media [27]. However, as far as we know, its application in Li-O2 batteries has not been reported. In this work, we propose to introduce CoNiO2 nanoneedle arrays on the surface of SCC-N via hydrothermal method to form a novel 3D free-standing cathode. This electrode combines the advantages of high efficient catalytic activity of CoNiO2, high conductivity of carbon skeleton and the 3D macroscopic frameworks of SCC-N. The Li-O2 batteries with this cathode exhibited an excellent specific capacity as high as 1654 mA h g−1 cathode at a current density of 0.05 mA cm-2, which is almost 2 times higher than that of SCC-N. In addition, the discharge/charge overpotential decreases and cycling performance is enhanced obviously because of the addition of CoNiO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation The synthesis process of SCC-N (N-doped carbon network derived from silkworm cocoon) is consistent with the previous literature [13]. Briefly, the silkworm cocoons bought from local markets were first cleaned with deionized water, and then cut into small discs with diameter of 16 mm. After soaking in saturated KCl aqueous solution for 24 h, the silkworm cocoons were removed and dried in an oven at 80 °C. The final samples (named as SCC-N) were prepared by calcining the silkworm cocoons, which adsorbed a large amount of KCl on the surface, at 900 °C for 2 h in N2 atmosphere and 30 min in NH3 atmosphere, respectively. The CoNiO2/SCC-N composites were prepared via hydrothermal process and subsequent thermal annealing. Typically, 5 mmol of Ni(NO3)2.6H2O, 5 mmol of Co(NO3)2.6H2O and 30 mmol urea were dissolved in 30 ml of water/ethanol solution (volume ratio = 1:1) with magnetic stirring at room temperature. After 30 min, the mixture was transferred to a 50 ml Teflon-lined autoclave with 5 pieces of the as-prepared SCC-N immersed into the reaction solution. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 150 °C for 6 h, and then cooled down to room temperature. The products were washed several times with distilled water and anhydrous ethanol and dried in oven at 60 °C. Finally, the NiCo-precursor/SCC-N composites were further annealed at 300 °C for 2 h in Ar atmosphere. The final sample was denoted as CoNiO2/SCC-N and the total weight of each CoNiO2/SCC-N electrode was about 8–10 mg. 2.2 Characterization The crystalline structure of the samples was examined by X-ray diﬀ ;raction system (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance) with Cu Kα radiation. The morphology and microstructures of the samples were recorded by a Hitachi SU8220 field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a FEI Tecnai-20 transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out by using an ESCLAB-250Xi apparatus with Al Kα radiation to characterize the chemical compositions. All the XPS peaks of the elements were corrected by using the C1 s peak (284.8 eV) as a reference. The CoNiO2 loading content is obtained by simultaneous thermal analysis (TG/DSC, NETZSCH, TAQ600) from room temperature to 700 °C under O2 atmosphere. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries was examined by using CR2025 coin type cells, which drilled with 17ⅹΦ1.0 mm holes on the positive shell for ensuring the O2 access. The free-standing CoNiO2/SCC-N or SCC-N was directly served as the cathode, while a Li metal plate (purity>99.99%) and 1 M LiCF3SO3 in tetra-ethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) (Sigma-Aldrich) was used as the anode and electrolyte, respectively. A glass filter with thickness of 0.68 mm (Whatman, GF/D) was employed to separate the anode and cathode electrode. For comparison, Super P/CP cathodes were prepared by spraying the aqueous slurry composed of Super P (Temical) and Nafion (5 wt %, Dupont) (mass ratio of 9:1) on the carbon paper. After being assembled in an argon-filled glove box (MBRAUN, H2O<0.5 ppm, O2<0.5 ppm), each coin cell was sealed in a glass bottle and then moved out of the glove box. Subsequently, the glass bottle filled with 1.0 atm pure O2 and the cells were rested for 5 h before testing. The cell performances were recorded by a Neware battery testing system (BTS-3008, Shenzhen Neware Co., Ltd.) at room temperature. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed on an electrochemical workstation (PARSTAT 4000) at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 between 2.0 and 4.5 V vs. Li+/Li. 3 Results and discussion The crystal structure of the as-prepared CoNiO2/SCC-N was confirmed by XRD analysis, and the patterns are shown in Fig. 1 . The broad peak at 2θ = 25° corresponds to the carbon diffraction. The distinct peaks are observed at 2θ values of 36.8°, 42.8°, 61.8°, and 74.0°, which can be indexed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of CoNiO2 phase (JCPDS 10-0188), with no impurity phase. XPS measurements were conducted to explore the elemental composition and chemical bonding state of the as-synthesized CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode, as shown in Figs 2 . The survey XPS spectrum (Fig. 2a) indicates the presence of Ni, Co, N and O as well as of C, which well corroborates the EDX results (Fig. S1). As shown in Fig. 2b, the doped N elements are inherited from the proteins in silkworm cocoon [28], which can be deconvoluted into three types: pyridine-N (∼398.3 eV), pyrrole-N (∼400.1 eV), and graphite-N type (∼401 eV), respectively [29]. The doping of N atoms could induce the defects of adjacent C atoms, while graphite-N and pyridine-N are considered as the active sites for enhancing the ORR activity of N-doped carbon [30,31]. However, compared with SCC-N [12], the content of doped N in CoNiO2/SCC-N is only 1.46% and the peak intensity of N 1 s is so weak to be almost undetectable; this is attributed to the surface of carbon that has been covered by CoNiO2, as well as to the limited XPS detection depth. As seen in Fig. 2c, it is clear that Ni 2p can be reasonably fitted with two spin-orbit doublets characteristic of Ni2+ and Ni3+ with two shakeup satellites (indicated as “Sat.”). The binding energy peaks at 855.8 eV and 873.4 eV correspond to Ni3+, while the binding peaks at 854.3 eV and 871.9 eV are assigned to Ni2+. Similarly, the high-resolution Co 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 2d) can be deconvoluted into two spin-orbit doublets characteristic of Co2+ and Co3+ with two shakeup satellites (Sat.), according to the binding energy. The peaks at binding energies of 779.5 and 794.9 eV are attributed to Co3+, whereas the peak sitting at 781.7 and 796.7 eV are ascribed to Co2+ [32–34]. These XPS results demonstrate the existence of mixed valence states of Ni3+/Ni2+ and Co3+/Co2+, implying the superior ORR/OER activity of CoNiO2/SCC-N, which enables the possible redox electrocatalytic activity towards the formation and decomposition of Li2O2. The morphology of the as-prepared CoNiO2/SCC-N were characterized by SEM, and the corresponding images are shown in Figs 3 . It is obvious that the whole electrode presents an interwoven network structure composed of microfibers, inheriting from the N-doped carbon nanonet derived from silkworm cocoon [12]. The CoNiO2 nanoneedles grown densely on the surface of carbon fiber, indicating the good attachment between the CoNiO2 and the carbon skeleton. The abundant channels between the carbon fibers are beneficial for O2 and electrolyte transport, while the CoNiO2 nanoneedles may increase the catalytic activity sites for ORR/OER compared with pure SCC-N (Fig. S2). Meanwhile, the carbon skeletons could ensure a reliable electric conductivity for CoNiO2 nanoneedles and provide capacious storage spaces for the discharge products [35,36]. As seen, at high magnification, the CoNiO2 nanoneedles are well dispersed with an average diameter of 10 nm and length 200–300 nm. A detailed architecture of CoNiO2/SCC-N was observed by the TEM micrographs given in Fig. 4 . Before testing, the electrode of CoNiO2/SCC-N was milled into powder and ultrasonicated for 30 min in anhydrous ethanol. Subsequently, the as-obtained suspension, containing the CoNiO2/C mixture, was prepared for TEM analysis (dropped onto the copper net for the sample preparation). From the high-resolution TEM image in Fig. 4a, it is revealed that the sample is composed of CoNiO2 nanoparticles with polycrystalline nature and amorphous carbon [27]. The interplanar spacings, appeared in Fig. 4b, are calculated to be 0.24 and 0.33 nm, and in good agreement with the inter-plane spacing of the (200) and (220) planes respectively of CoNiO2 [22,24,27]. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping analysis (Fig. 4c) also verified that the Co, Ni, O, C and N elements were evenly distributed in CoNiO2/SCC-N. In-situ cyclic voltammetry (CV) was employed to examine the electrocatalytic activity of the different cathodes, measured in O2-saturated non-aqueous LiTFSI/TEGDME electrolyte at a scan rate of 0.5 mV·s−1 in the potential range of 2-4.5 V vs Li/Li+. Fig. 5 shows the CV curves of Super P/CP, SCC-N, and CoNiO2/SCC-N. The initial potentials toward ORR of CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode is ∼2.89 V, which is positively shifted by 130 and 170 mV compared with that for Super P/CP and SCC-N, respectively. In addition, the cathodic peak current density (corresponding to ORR) of the Li-O2 battery with CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode is 0.046 mA g-1, which is much higher than that of Super P/CP (0.027 mA g-1) and SCC-N (0.039 mA g-1), further demonstrating the superior ORR catalytic activity of CoNiO2/SCC-N. Furthermore, compared with Super P/CP and SCC-N cathodes, an obvious oxidation peak during anodic scan can be observed on the CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode, indicating the better catalytic activity toward OER of the CoNiO2/SCC-N [37,38]. The electrochemical performance of the as-prepared cathodes was examined in Li-O2 batteries. All the achieved capacities reported in this work were normalized to the total mass of the cathode (mAh gcathode −1). Fig. 6 a displays the first full discharge-charge profiles for the Li-O2 batteries at a current density of 0.05 mA cm-2 within the cut-off potential range of 2.2–4.2 V vs. Li/Li+. It can be seen that the CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode can deliver an initial discharge capacity of 1654 mAh g−1 cathode, which is almost 2 times higher than that of SCC-N (840 mA h g−1 cathode). By thermogravimetric analysis, it was found that the content of CoNiO2 catalysts is only 12.9% in composite materials (see Fig. S3). So, based on the active mass of the catalysts, the specific capacity reaches up to 12,821 mAh g−1. Compared the cathodes with ingenious structures reported in the literature [13,39–44], this capacity is quite competitive (as shown in Table 1 below). Additionally, the overpotential of the battery with CoNiO2/SCC-N at discharge and charge stage is only 0.18 V and 1.04 V, which is apparently lower than those of Li-O2 batteries with Super P/CP and SCC-N, attributing to the superior ORR/OER catalytic activity of CoNiO2/SCC-N. The rate performance of the Li-O2 batteries with CoNiO2/SCC-N was further evaluated by different current densities, as shown in Fig. 6 b. Obviously, the specific capacity sharply declines with the current density increasing for both CoNiO2/SCC-N and SCC-N cathodes. However, as can be seen, even when the current density is increased to 0.1 mA cm−2, the capacity of the 3D free-standing CoNiO2/SCC-N still remains as high as 513 mA h g-1 cathode. For comparison, the discharge specific capacity of SCC-N was only 96 mA h g-1 cathode at 0.1 mA cm−2. The cycle performance of the as-synthesized CoNiO2/SCC-N was studied with capacity limited method at a current density of 0.05 mA cm−2 and a limited capacity of 0.25 mA h cm−2. As shown in Fig. 6c, there is no capacity decay even after 147 cycles for the CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode, while SCC-N cathode can only cycle 60 times (see Fig. S4a). This result also stands as a splendid cycle life compared with ever-reported results, highlighting the superior rechargeability of the Li-O2 batteries with the aid of CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode. In addition, it is observed that the discharge/charge curves remain stable and show no obvious variation. As shown in Fig. 6d, the discharge terminal voltage is still higher than 2.7 V and the charge terminal voltage is below 4.0 V after 147 cycles, which is much better than that of SCC-N (see Fig. S4b). The high specific capacity, the good rate capability and the outstanding cyclic stability is likely to have benefited from its favorable mesostructure: oxygen and electrolyte can be supplied by the carbon nanonet channels and the CoNiO2 nanoneedles deliver more three-phase regions for ORR/OER [45–47]. SEM was employed to investigate the morphology evolution of the CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode at different stages. As clearly can be seen from Figs 7(a and b), the surface of the electrode is obviously coated by the insoluble species after the 1 st discharge. At the end of the 1 st charging, the CoNiO2 needles were essentially restored to the pristine appearance, confirming that most of the discharge products have been decomposed during the charge process [Figs 7(c–e)]. Hence, we suggest that the 3D macroporous structure of CoNiO2/SCC-N electrode not only improves the transport of oxygen and electrolyte, but also provides simultaneously larger three-phase contact areas and larger space for Li2O2 deposition, which underpin enhancing the specific capacity and cycle performance of Li-O2 batteries. To further explore the reversibility of the Li-O2 battery with CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode, the formation and decomposition behavior of discharge products at different stages should be diagnosed. To this aim, Figs 8 show the XRD pattern and the XPS spectra of the CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode at different discharge-charge stages. As shown in Fig. 8a, it is clear that two diffraction peaks at around 34.8° and 40.5° are observed after discharge, which can be indexed to the (100), (101) and (102) planes of Li2O2 (JCPDF 09-0355). On the other hand, XPS confirmed that there is only one peak centered at 54.7 eV, indicating that Li2O2 is the main discharge product. Some miscellaneous peaks originated from LiOH and Li2CO3 can be detected by XRD and XPS after recharge [1,48–50]. From Fig. 8b, it can be seen that the Li 1 s XPS spectrum can be deconvoluted into two peaks, corresponding to Li2O2 (54.7 eV) and Li2CO3 (55.3 eV), respectively. The LiOH and Li2CO3 may be associated with the reaction between Li2O2 and H2O and CO2 when the XRD samples were exposed in air. However, we must admit that there is a little Li2O2 that can be detected after the 1st charge, though its XPS peak strength has been reduced. Due to continuous accumulation of the insulating Li2O2 and Li2CO3, the electrode will be progressively passivated and the channels will be blocked, leading to the attenuation of the cyclic stability. On the basis of the SEM and electrochemical results, an electrochemical mechanism for the cells using CoNiO2/SCC-N was proposed, which is illustrated in the scheme depicted in Fig. 9 . Compared with SCC-N, the growth of CoNiO2 nanoneedles greatly increases the catalytic activity site. Meanwhile, the interwoven carbon fibers can ensure the conductivity of the air electrode, thus enhancing the kinetics of the electrochemical reactions. During the discharging process, the reaction between O2 and Li+ occurs on the surface of CoNiO2 nanoneedles. With the increase of the depth of the reaction, the insoluble Li2O2 gradually covers the surface of the electrode, which eventually leads to the termination of the discharge. Following the charge process, Li2O2 particles were decomposed at a lower potential charge due to the superior catalytic properties of CoNiO2. Meanwhile, the reduction of charge overpotential also avoids the corrosion of the N-doped carbon nanonet substrate, resulting in a better cycle performance. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, silkworm cocoons were used as raw materials to prepare N-doped carbon nanonets. Via hydrothermal process and subsequent thermal annealing, CoNiO2 nanoneedles array grown on the N-doped carbon nanonet to form 3D binder-free air cathodes for Li-O2 batteries. The cathode architecture incorporated a unique design feature that consists of one-dimensional nanoneedle arrays decorated with carbon microfibers. The result is a Li-O2 battery with CoNiO2/SCC-N cathode. This 3D binder-free cathode deliver a high specific capacity of 1654 mAh g−1 cathode, and a lower discharge/charge overpotential compared to those of Super P/CP and SCC-N, as well as a stable performance for 147 cycles. The excellent electrochemical performance is likely to have benefited because: (i) the CoNiO2 nanoneedles enlarge the catalytic active sites and thus enhance the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2, (ii) the open and through structure of the interwoven carbon fibers offer ample space for the Li2O2 deposition and facilitate mass transport, and (iii) the side reaction caused by the decomposition of the binder can be avoided. Meanwhile, compared with Ni foam, carbon paper or graphene foam, the cost of the air cathode with biomass derived 3D carbon carrier is greatly reduced. Combining high-efficient transition metal oxide electrocatalyst and 3D binder-free N-doped carbon derived from biomass is a promising technique for the preparation of low-cost and high-performance cathodes for Li-O2 batteries. Acknowledgments The authors gratefully acknowledge the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (2013QNA48), Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province of China (Project Number: BK20160239) and Key Laboratory of Coal-based CO2 Capture and Geological Storage, Jiangsu Province (China University of Mining and Technology, Project Number: 2016B06) for financial support. Prof. Tsiakaras has been financially supported by the Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation (Mega-Grant, contract no. 14.Z50.31.0001) and co‐financed by the European Union and Greek national funds through the Operational Program Competitiveness, Entrepreneurship and Innovation, under the call RESEARCH – CREATE – INNOVATE (project code:T1EDK-02442). coredata.dc:description: Lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries are considered as promising candidates for future energy storage systems due to their super-high theoretical energy densities. However, the poor cyclic stability and low efficiency still hinder their commercialization, which is mainly attributed to the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) processes. In the present work, we fabricated a three-dimensional (3D) air cathode composed of CoNiO2 nanoneedles decorated N-doped porous carbon nanonet (CoNiO2/SCC-N), using silkworm cocoons as the raw materials and following the carbonization-hydrothermal route. The as fabricated batteries, with CoNiO2/SCC-N air cathode, are exhibited a very good discharge capacity of 1654 mAh g−1 cathode at a current density of 0.05 mA cm-2, presenting a stability of over 147 cycles. The observed electrochemical performance is attributed to the synergistic effect of the enhanced ORR/OER activity after the introduction of CoNiO2 and the efficient mass transport characteristics of SCC-N.
coredata.dc:title: Highly performing free standing cathodic electrocatalysts for Li-O2 batteries: CoNiO2 nanoneedle arrays supported on N-doped carbon nanonet
